http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/20927.html

my mom and i head into Oia to rent quads and tool around santorini.  we stop along the way and i'm traipsing around like an idiot while my mom is in this little shop buying stuff.  i wander across the street and up this set of stairs to snap some pics.  note - for greece, these stairs are totally par for the course on the hazardous scale.  no rail, fairly steep, and totally uneven.  i deftly scale them and make a mental note of one particular stair that basically has a huge hole in it. i'm looking all over and snapping some great shots when i see my mom come out of the shop across the street.  i start yapping at her about something, bearing in mind the scary step ahead.  however, i apparently TOTALLY overestimated my ability to traverse the OTHER seemingly benign stairs and on about the second step down i completely roll my ankle.  i hear a loud snap while somehow managing to brace myself on the wall to avoid completely biting it.  my mom comes running over asking me all sorts of questions about how i fell and what i stepped on and i want to kill her so she will stop asking me questions while i am doubled over praying to god that my ankle isnt broken.

fast forward to today, with my ankle approximately the size of a baseball.  with the help of some advil i have reasonable range of motion, which makes me less inclined to go to a doctor to get it checked out.  my sister and brother find it quite humorous to walk in front of me and loudly announce every step and hole that we come across.  i figure i will try to make it to the next island or hopefully back home before i have to deal with it.  good plan, eh?

leave me some addresses and you will get some postcards in return.  :)
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/20685.html

i may have broken my ankle.  well played.

guess we will see how aetna works internationally.

You scored as agnosticism. You are an agnostic. Though it is generally taken that agnostics neither believe nor disbelieve in God, it is possible to be a theist or atheist in addition to an agnostic. Agnostics don't believe it is possible to prove the existence of God (nor lack thereof). Agnosticism is a philosophy that God's existence cannot be proven. Some say it is possible to be agnostic and follow a religion; however, one cannot be a devout believer if he or she does not truly believe.

what i find most interesting about this quiz is the last line. there is a difference between believing that god exists and believing that his existence can be proven. now maybe i am reading this wrong and this is not what our friend callalily19 intended to suggest. i am more inclined, however, to believe that she simply glossed over this important distinction. thanks for your glib editorializing, callalily19. does this count as a real update? hard to say... :)

so its 4am and ive been awake for an hour.  why?  because my upstairs neighbor has like 4 friends over and theyre obviously making ZERO effort to be quiet at all.  this would be much less irritating if this were the first second third fourth fifth time this has happened.  much less irritating if this WERENT what happened more often than not BOTH nights of every weekend.  much less irritating if he hadnt woken me up at similar times all week.  

mildly less irritating if i havent asked him to at least TRY to be quiet 2 times before.  

slightly less irritating if he werent 33 YEARS OLD.  i swear to fucking god.  he moved in without silverware or furniture.  

GROW UP.

http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/14667.html

after rooting through clothes in my closet, i took a break to look through my 'box of favorite stuff' that cait suggested i start keeping in high school.  it's basically full of concert tickets, random hand-written notes, a couple of christmas cards, pictures, and some letters and emails.  i sat and read a few of the letters and all of the emails.  it's really weird how people's perceptions of me change.  as it turns out, i've had a lot of people who really respected me.  things change a lot.  not that people don't respect me, but it certainly isn't the same.  i'm really not whining, just observing. i'm curious how i was different then that made people want to pour their hearts out to me about how i changed their lives.  it feels really foreign.  for the first time in my life i'm actually starting to wonder if i would recognize much about the person i was a few years ago.   

i have the feeling that i believed the nice things that people said to me then more than i do now.  at the same time, it was more convincing then.  what is that?

then i get to the emmy emails.  and i feel like a complete jackass.  and she called me on not being very perceptive.  i was a 5 year old, and she knew it.  but only partly, cuz who could have reasonably expected that i was such a kid.  



so it has been a weird combination of feeling really important and really stupid.  
what an odd evening.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/14251.html

so i got home yesterday after a pretty fantastic road trip home from DC.  we revelled in the awesomeness that was gov love and talked about what we want to change next year.  then patrick and i parted ways while sb and guppy went north on 75.  big bummer.

i get home to an empty house and a chemotherapy schedule sitting out on the counter.  so apparently my dad is starting chemo.  they think they found something on his kidney, and that the cancer is in his bones too.  

i dont really know what to do or say.  
im always on the edge of crying.  
i dont really know how bad it is.  it sounds pretty bad.  

thanks agent orange.  youre the best.  

im putting this on here in hopes of having to verbally tell fewer people.  i still havent told anyone out loud.  i think it will suck very much.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/13818.html

sent the session 5 kiddies home today.  woot woot.  

just played about 5 hours of mafia after watching i heart huckabees with like 20 ppl.  fun.  

a lot of ppl are assuming i'm coming back here next year.  thing is, i basically have to arrange my life around doing so. ie not even trying to get a real job that would last more than about 10 months.  i've also begun to question whether i even have the desire.  it's hard when everything starts to feel like an uphill battle.  

3 ppl on my staff so far are interested in having my job next year.  it makes me really happy.  one of my goals was to end the summer with lots of people wanting my job cuz i made it look easy and fun.  hopefully its not cuz they think im incompetent and that they could do a much better job.  i actually dont think that's it though.  

it seems like i'm always listening to jack johnson when i update this thing. 

my great uncle died on arrival day.  

i havent really cried about it yet.  or even thought about it.  i was close a couple of times at the airport but then i had to talk to students so i choked it back.  my uncle jerry was a pretty great guy.  WWII vet, raised my dad, had an orange grove in florida.  

still not going to really think about it.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/13508.html

just sent the session 3 kids home yesterday.  i'm totally exhausted.  hosted a huge birthday bash for a couple of people on staff, and celebrated the new harry potter book.  this basically meant about 30 people in my room last night.  after a few hours of merrymaking and cigars on the balcony, i ended up escaping at about 2am to go play mafia in b hull's room.  good fun.  

this is our last break of any size, the next 2 are only 1 day.  buggin.  i cant believe we are already half done.  more than half technically, because our 6 day break is over too.  it's flying actually.  

i love my staff.  they are almost all newbies, but they are fantastic.  i want to bottle them up and put them in my pocket.  for safe keeping.  

the whole head TA thing is going well.  i'm starting to get into a groove and i have a better idea of what i need to be doing.  and i'm forcing myself to step back and do less.  which is going well for me.  

i'm less tired than i was the last two summers.  which is odd, cuz i'm doing more work.  shrug.  

i have no idea what i am doing come august 9th.  scary.  i really try hard not to think about it.  it makes me wish i was still in school.  i like the security of going back every fall.  fack.

ps i HATE dc weather.  

tiger is gonna win the open.  woot woot.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/13139.html

being home is fantastic.  being in london feels like it was a dream.  i think i'm going to miss it really soon.  may have to go visit patsy while he is doing the LSE thing.  this is of course if i have any money.  hmmm.  first step - get a fucking job.

i have some prospects in chicago - thanks felic, DC - chrispelkey you rock, fresno (of all godforsaken places) - random lawyer i met in italy, and aa - props to stino.  other than that i'm just winging it.  i need to get going on my resume.  did i mention that i HATE writing cover letters?  

also need to chat with the history dept and try to convince them that my UCL history classes count for something so i can get my diploma.  

last weekend was pretty good. seeing everyone was great, despite a rocky start.  the BANG! was hott- i don't really remember much besides doing tequila shots and playing darts.  there must have been more than that...

went to panera 3 times, jj twice.  still need to hit charleys/pizza bobs.  badly.  this weekend, kids.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/12710.html

i'm so hung over.  

my hands are shaking.  it's tough to type.  stomach/head are as you would imagine.  feelin like i'm 18 or something.  who get's hung over anymore - seriously.

i think i woulda slept it off if i hadn't gotten 2 hours of sleep.  gotta go buy theatre tix tho, really wanna see brian dennehy in death of a salesman. 

last night was random.  met a guy named gabe who works for the engineering company that is designing the new umich art museum.  

dreading the tube ride.  bleh.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/12531.html

working on my last paper.  by this time tomorrow i will have written 9 2500-word papers since i've been here.  that's a fuckin lot of papers in my book.  

suzy gets in tomorrow morning!  i can't wait to see her and show her around - she's gonna love it. 

i can't believe my time here is almost up.  a week from today i'm heading home.   so much packing to do.  and so many last minute sites to see and visit for the first/last time.  

i'm really going to miss london.  a lot.  

jack johnson's new album is great.  thank you stine.  

can't wait to see everyone.  it's gonna be a good few weeks before DC.  :)

that was a very incredulous entry.  ha.  i'm just so SHOCKABLE.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/12174.html

just checked my directory profile.  i'm officially listed as alumni.  it was startlingly terrifying.  like pit of my stomach fear.  i think the whole being gone really distanced me from the reality that i'm done with undergrad.  god i hate even saying it.  

hello quarter life crisis.  

i really need to get moving on my JD.  that will help, i think.

on the bright side, it's a beautiful day in london.  had a great lunch at the curry leaf with andrew jaime and tiff then headed to grab some coffee and read the sunday times.  yea, i'm 40 yrs old.  i know.  it's interesting to read all about blair's plans to invade iraq back in april 2002.  some memos were just leaked talking about creating justifications for war, front page story.  an interesting contrast.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/11892.html

things are going pretty well.  i have nothing to do really, so i guess things couldnt get much better.  well i could have money, or be completely done with papers, but ah well.  

saw the british museum the other day.  highlights included seeing more of the acropolis than when i actually SAW the acropolis, and a room full of 16-18th century clocks... most of which were still ticking!  cool.  

met jaime and andrew in camden yesterday, and caught up on the wonders of paris and, er, bologna.  had some of the cheapest coffee in london, going back for more today.  yum.

did i mention i love camden?  cant stop going there.

gotta hit the tate modern sometime soon.  i keep hearing its amazing.  

might be coming home another 5 days early.  andrew is out of money and ready to peace out.  doesnt really matter to me either way.  

my life is really good right now.  im really enjoying being in london.  going home is going to be really great.  then heading back to DC is going to be awesome.  then, the infinite abyss...  but until august, life is really pretty great.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/11562.html

im awake at 9.25.  of my own volition.  the whole gettin up at like 6-7 whilst on our trip has officially messed with my sleep schedule.  which is a good thing cuz i was really gettin sick of that staying up all night thing.  

plus i gotta write 2 10-pg papers over the next two days, so its def a good thing that im up this early.  wow the next 48 hours or so are gonna blow.

the trip was crazy.  too much to talk about.  well, or type about i guess.  i feel smarter, more well-rounded.  i guess thats what travel does.

it feels like april didnt even happen this year.  like the last 3 weeks were a void in time.  or a break from it.  something like that.  

im only here for about another month.  weird.

hope everyone's lives are going well!
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/11358.html

totally was in rome yesterday.

totally had conclave at the sistine chapel.

they totally picked the pope.

i was totally sitting in an internet cafe freaking out on a caffeine high and frantically searching for a hostel for that night in florence before heading to termini to meet andrew and tiff and grab a train.

totally didnt even find out that they picked the pope until we turned on the tv in florence about 5 hours later.

life is weird. 

2 more nights and then back to london with me.  then only a month and back to the states with me.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/11149.html

it's really hard to describe how FUCKING amazing the acropolis is.  

just so you know.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/10917.html

leaving tomorrow.  well technically saturday at 2am.  totally didnt get the papers done that i needed to.  so i need to write like 1500 words and read about 100 pgs tomorrow along with packing, laundry, last-minute errands, etc.  sweeeet.  

to lapse into nslc speak for a moment, my ATA looks awesome.  his name is lester and i shall call him lester prynne and he is from queens and he likes indie.  cute.  

REALLY hoping i get my digital camera tomorrow.  and my backpack.  odds arent good.  :(
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/10505.html

which evidently is a bank holiday here.  for some reason i can't remember whether good friday is a federal holiday at home, and whether stores close and shit.  which seems to imply no, but i really could be just that clueless.  anyway, london pretty much shuts down.  protestant work ethic my ass.  not that i'm complaining, don't get me wrong :)  it's just funny.  some guy at orientation warned us about the 'protestant work ethic' of the british and how we would have to work so hard.  probably a pretty meaningless thing to say to a big group of americans...

procrastinating hardcore.  like wow.  the whole class being over thing is really throwing me.  i have 2.5 pprs to do by next friday, really need to get going on those... fack.  

oh, so i have this hilarious 15-second footage from going out a couple nights ago.  if you want me to send it to you, lemme know.

so i'm getting the feeling that this terri shiavo thing is all over the news at home?  anyway, thank god the S/C isn't hearing that shit.  

and why doesn't anyone seem to be talking about the fake news clips that the bush administration is producing?  doesn't THAT seem like a big fucking deal?

bah.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/10239.html

so stine made the rather obvious observation that i still managed to miss that i'm probably not sleeping well because i DONT DO ANYTHING.  DUH! damn.  

today was the last day of class.  i skipped one of em.  totally umich style.  

it's really weird to not know what i want to do come sept.  like really not know.  no preference.  i'm not really used to that.  i liked the comfort of having my life mapped out.  it was soothing.  

anyone else think the terri shiavo thing is fuckin insane?  i like it how the republican party is supposed to represent small government.  but what they really mean is no economic regulation so corporations can do what they want. not to mention nonexistent social programs so they don't have to waste precious time/energy ferreting away money in offseas ventures to keep it from going into the hands of black welfare mothers who just dont work hard enough, and old people who cant afford their meds but who shouldve managed their 401k's better so its their fault anyway. yet as far as social issues go (gay marriage, abortion, euthanasia, shall i continue?) the government's reach can't stretch far enough.  

it makes me not want to come back.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/9735.html

so the last few days have been full of the 'what the hell am i doing with my life?' questions.  i've really never had those before and i thought ppl were full of shit when they obsessed about it, but i'm starting to understand.  it's so close on the horizon.  after september i dont have a plan.  so here are my options as i see them:

- find a job in the DC area working for the govt or a private firm as a paralegal/legal assistant of some kind and live (hopefully) with chrispelkey.
- find a job in AA and live with stine/bryan/jessie.
- apply to the 12-month masters program at LSE and live with patrick.  

here are my considerations thus far:

- DC would be really pragmatic and i could get my foot in the door at a place like the justice dept.  looks good on a resume.  there are lots of postings too, so lots of chances in both the public/private sector.  love DC.  love chrispelkey.

- AA would be great because i could extend the whole college thing a little farther and be close to home which is something that i havent been and wont be for another 5 months or so.  also would take advantage of having so many friends still in the area for one more year.  no job there though... and no leads.  i loves my AA kids.  and AA. 

- london is, well, london.  the masters program would be a great move academically and professionally.  hi, i could get into any law school anywhere.  i think i would like to extend my london stay (though its hard to judge right now) and living with patsy would be great fun too (he's studying a year abroad at LSE).  however, i question my ability to work hard in this environment and i have NO interest in writing a dissertation.  

seriously, input?  i really need it.

btw, when did i become someone that up and leaves home?  like really?  i never thought i would be that person who would get their shit together and get a job in DC or study in london.  i really can't believe thats who ive become.  

i really like home, despite all evidence to the contrary.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/9638.html

went to club motherfucker tonight.  saw... fack what was their name...something that started with a D and had !!! at the end.  fuck.  anyway.  waited about an hour outside to get in.  'sorry, one in, one out.'  christ.  but it was fine, actually.  i was perfectly content waiting in line.  actually had more fun in the queue than inside.  the gravy boat?  shit i cant rememebr thje name of the band.  but htey were fun.  a girl was up there in a pink/black striped shirt and she was ownin it.  funny.  but then it got less fun...  ehhh.  reminded me of the bang, but none of MY indiefucks around.  :)  when the dj's started the music started out well but deteriorated.  didnt feel like dancing to any of it by the end.  

still, a quality night.  def an experience.  

gravy train!!!

thats it./

got the rejection letter from georgetown.  they accept about 3.8% of all their applicants, and i wasn't in that 3.8%.  seriously, why did i think i could get in by applying at the end of december?  so i knew it was only a matter of time before the rejection came, but i still had that stupid glimmer of hope.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/8316.html

so i woke up at 11 this morning.  naturally.  weird!  think i might need to go back to sleep.

hmmmmmmm wish i had a point.  

patrick just got accepted to LSE, so it looks like he's comin here for a school year in the fall.  i recommended it too, which makes me realize that i am pretty content here.  despite innumerous frustrations that relate mostly to UCL.  mebbe LSE will be better.  anything would be better really.  well mebbe not ANYTHING...  

met andrew and his sister and her friend in the theatre district for a drink.  after i wound up on the dodgy end of drury lane (NOT where the muffin man lives, i trust) and andrew basically saved me.  then we headed back and hung out at a pub called the fitzrovia.  it was a good time.

thinking of going to camden today.  perhaps to spend some more money that i dont have.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/8025.html

just got back from paris a few hours ago.  wasn't that amped about going.  i don't really care much about french culture or history, so it didn't really matter to me.  

wow.  it completely blew my hair back.  i kept finding myself thinking 'wow this is completely incredible.'  then i realized that it's pretty much just an incredible place.  despite the occasional stench often arising from dog shit on the sidewalk, or the ridiculousness that can be the french people.  my first glimpse coming out of the metropolitain was, naturally, the arc d' triomphe.  spent forever trying to find the hotel, then went back to the shamps-elysees, which was once again stunning.  you can really see exactly what our capital is based on.  it is really cool to have seen so many imperial cities in my life.  

saturday we went to monmartre and saw the sacree coure which is the highest point in paris.  well other than the eiffel tower.  so of course the view was literally breath-taking.  then got crepes and wandered around where picasso liked to hang out.  and tolous-lautrec, of course.  wow i think i'm really bad at spelling french names.  ah well.  then went to the musee d'orsay and saw tons of impressionist pieces.  including some monets that i love and have actually seen before, which was odd...  then went for dinner at trocadero (across the seine from the tower) and then walked across a huge park and over a bridge to the tower.  just in time for it to start sparkling (it shimmers for about 10 min. on the hour since they installed more lights for the millenium).  my mom couldn't handle going all the way to the top of the tower, so i stuffed the buds in my ears and listened to the ipod alone looking across the parisian rooftops and twinkling lights.  listened mostly to the garden state soundtrack which i hardly ever listen to.  esp. frou frou cuz yea, that song is amazing and was so perfect for the moment.  

today was the musee d'picasso in the morning and a really quick spin through the louvre before heading to the airport.  the musee d'picasso was mildly disappointing because it didn't have much from his blue/rose periods at the turn of the century or from his peace posters in the 1960s.  which are naturally my favorite pieces.  but it was still hott.  i'm really obsessed with how he does faces, he always seems to capture expressions that are so real and familiar.  the louvre was decent, of course just skimmed the surface cuz it's MASSIVE.  saw the venus de milo and of course the mona lisa.  the mona lisa was better than i expected because everyone said it was disappointing so my expectations were rather low.  it ended up being bigger than i imagined, and the colors were really rich and deep.  so yea, crazy amounts of art.  and saw some beautiful streets and buildings and vistas.  and ate some great food.

so in a nutshell, i loved paris and will have to go back.  which i never expected to say.  

oh yea, and i almost used my leatherman to slit the throat of a woman on air france who told me i had to check my bag because the leatherman was forbidden.  despite the fact that i got there without a problem.  then was almost blatantly rude to a stranger for the first time in my life.  it was a good thing my mom was talking to them instead of me.  the fuckin bastards, they totally had it coming.

note: don't ever do paris for the first time in only 2.5 days and expect to be anywhere near jovial by the end.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/7807.html

so emmy is the only reason that girls' state wasn't a complete waste of my life.  i don't talk to her as much as i used to, but that's pretty easy to do since we used to talk for bout 5-10 hours a day.  i don't even remember what we would talk about, but we really never ran out of things to say.  

emmy is a rather good writer.  though she probably doesn't do it enough.  

emmy introduced me to ani.  seriously how priceless is that.  i don't love ani as much as some, but i can't imagine my life without her.  kind of like i can't reflect on late high school without thinking of emmy.  it's funny how many small ways she managed to change me.    

emmy gives really good hugs.  

she is the only person who has ever made me think that, maybe, sometimes, i'm kinda hott  ;)

she was the first in a long line of friends from that glorious family that i now can't seem to get enough of.  she also got me to stop saying 'fag,' thank GOD.  i used to say it all the time.  

she punches REALLY hard.  

i'm sad that i don't know emmy as well as i used to.  i don't feel that awkwardness that time apart tends to bring though.  

my aa friends would be totally obsessed with her if they knew her.  i can't imagine what would happen if they ever met.  

it seems like almost all of my comments about her are in terms of me.  i think that says something.  what, you ask?  well connect the fuckin dots.  i'm not gonna spoon-feed you.

let me take a moment to talk to you about chrispelkey.  he has this incredible laugh that you wouldn't believe unless you heard it.  you know how it's so rewarding when you can get someone to laugh who doesn't laugh very often?  chrispelkey is an interesting character because he isn't stingy with his laughter, but even so it never ever ever gets old.  everytime i make him laugh it's a victory, even though i get to hear his laugh all the time.  talk about having my cake and eating it too...

chrispelkey's face crinkles into this gleeful grin after making a delightfully crass remark.

chrispelkey has an inner sadness that makes you want to do anything to make it stop.  

chrispelkey is one of the sexiest men i know, even though he really doesn't seem to buy that he's totally hott.

i envy how many people chrispelkey has around him who think he is amazing.  

he always knows when to offer me a cigarette.  

he never even has to say anything.  his presence really is always enough.  i feel lucky when i get to be near him.  

he is inherently comforting.       

i wish i had met him sooner.  the idea that we went to the same fuckin school for 3 years without knowing each other drives me crazy.  

these are just a few reasons why chrispelkey rocks my fuckin socks off.

a sobering fact:  11,500 applied to georgetown law last year for a spot in a 450-person incoming class.  seriously, why did i think i would get in by applying in december?  why did i think it would be ok to apply only there and wisconsin, when i don't even want to go to wisconsin?  i'm a huge fucking idiot.  they accept about 1 out of 22.  dammit.  any ideas what i should do post-nslc while i REapply for law school for the 2006-2007 school year?  anyone?  this is gonna be the biggest rejection of my life thus far.  totally not looking forward to it :-(

definitely didn't leave my dorm today.  which also means that i definitely didn't spend any money.  it's really damn cold out.  i feel guilty that i didn't really experience anything today.  i'm putting a lot of pressure on myself, and a lot of guilt follows when i don't go somewhere cool every day.  that's a lot to expect, i should get over it.

so someone stole my fucking bumpersticker from my door last night.  it really pisses me off.  my sister gave it to me for christmas.  coupled with the theft of my kerry-edwards sticker from my car, i'm getting inordinately pissed!  so the kerry-edwards sticker was free, and the sorryeverybody one probly cost my sister about 2 bucks.  but this obviously isn't the point.  the part that peeves me the most is that they were both expressions of my political beliefs, and they got utterly disrespected.  seeing as i basically live for my political ideals, it's such a personal attack and i'm having a hard time getting over it.  i'd like to think that someone couldn't resist them so they took them for themselves, but something tells me that's bullshit.  maybe it's offensive to put a political sticker on my door, like it's too confrontational.  but seriously, that seems lame.  

there is something poetic about getting it stolen on inauguration day.  something tells me that wasn't lost on the thief.  

i doubt it was an american, cuz i've gotten tons of compliments on it from practically everyone in my hall.  at least, not an american on our floor.  weird.      

god, i can't even express or justify why it makes me so angry.  :-(  

on a lighter note, went to karaoke night at the pint pot last night.  was really fun at first, but then got super packed and overrun by annoying americans.  think touchdowns crowd.  DAMN.  i knew a ton of them too, even more irritating.  obviously i'm not saying that all americans are annoying, i haven't become that much of a snob.  but there are a ridiculous share of annoying ones here at ucl.  whoa.  

looks like i might have a bartender there in my back pocket tho, she hooked us up hardcore and i tipped her well for it.  she said she loved me about 4 times.  :-)

ok, about to take a nap.  getting up for class was REALLY rough.

i've been listening to a lot of 3eb and rilo kiley lately.  that's really weird.  haven't listened to 3eb since like high school.  it's oddly comforting though.  and takeoffs and landings just makes me smile at it's darkness and cynicism.  sometimes it's nice to get some honest pessimism instead of empty optimism.  i'm really not that dark though.  not always :-)

ok, seriously rambling.
http://rabidcucumber.livejournal.com/4231.html

so this was a big step for me:  i took off both my livestrong and mgoblue bracelets on sunday.  i found a cool brown and white bone bracelet at camden market, and decided that it was time.  they are lovingly stowed with the rest of my jewelry.  i'm guessing i will put them back on sometime when i get home, but for now i feel like it is time for something different.  i have definitely begun to get in touch with my hippie side, which is weird since living in ann arbor for 3.5 years didn't even touch it.  i really didn't think i had such a side, but here it is, bit by bit!  weird.  sometimes i miss the bracelets, but i think this is a good move.  still sporting the pink one on the other wrist.  it works well with my watch.  anyway.  

andrew and tiffany and i went to portabello road over by notting hill today.  it was ok, but the market wasn't all set up because it wasn't the weekend.  i think i prefer camden still, but i will have to check out portabello on the weekend to do a fair comparison.  it was nice to get out on the other side of town and see the city from a bus instead of travelling underground in the tube.  saw the marble arch for the first time, which is evidently where they used to hang people.  it was really chilling and awesome to catch a glimpse of from the bus.  

i'm trying really hard to live in the moment while i am here, but it's really hard when i don't exactly know what i am doing after august.  i can't wait to head back to nslc, which is something i never thought i would say.  in a perfect world, i will get accepted to georgetown and chris pelkey will get a job out there and we will find a cute little apartment and i will start law school in the fall.  i wish it weren't so far from home, but at the same time i can drive home in a day, or fly home in like an hour.  but i'm trying not to get ahead of myself because i haven't been accepted yet and i totally applied late!  i've never been so anxious about getting an acceptance letter before.  if i don't get in there i need to figure out something else to do for a year.  

also got some random friendliness from a friend of a friend who is studying here, which is really cool.  she offered to take me to some places she likes to hang out, so i will prob take her up on that sometime.

still looking for some actually funny people.  the serious lack of people who can make me laugh over here is killing me minute by minute.  i've never appreciated my friends at home so much before.

just got back from camden town, which rocked my fuckin world.  bought a couple of small things, but REALLY wanted some amazing amber jewelry.  it's been a long time since i've seen rings and necklaces that could make me drool, but they were incredible.  and expensive, but i'm gonna have to splurge.  we only spent a couple of hours there, but we are def going back.

went to a club called popstarz on friday.  it was free before 11, so we were literally running through the tube trying to get there on time.  showed up to a line wrapped around the building, so ended up paying 5 pounds to get in, which isn't terrible.  met a couple of brits on the way, and they were delightfully shady and funny.  andrew thought it was a gay club, but turns out it's pride only on sat and tues nights.  it was kinda nice not to be one of the only straight people there though!  and there were plenty of the gay to go around for andrew too.  one of the guys we were dancing with offered me 'poppers,' which andrew looked up the next day and found out it's something sort of like nitrous oxide, from what i understand.  apparently it only lasts like 5 minutes.  i definitely passed, and watched him snort it out of a little vile.  my first time being offered drugs at a club :)  i'm so awesome now. 

i should really do some actual work now, seeing as i've only read about 50 pgs in a week.  no one does work here.  still haven't figured that one out yet.  

i miss everyone!  tell me that you're coming to see me.

so i checked out my first books from the ucl library. i'm such a badass. i didn't get how the cataloguing system worked, so i just walked down the hallway and happened upon the ancient history section. walked up to it, found my professor's book, and another one for next week just for kicks. haven't totally conquered my fear of the morass that is the library, but i feel better than i did. two of the girls in my hall that i hang out with a lot haven't heard of atari. correction, they had heard of it vaguely but didn't know what it was. one goes to penn, the other cornell. sat downstairs in the dining hall talking to a couple of (american) guys for like 1.5 hours, which was cool. so that makes probably 20 american kids that i know. other nationalities: 0. i'm starting to get used to it though. i basically am existing in a pocket of americans, but they are pretty easy to meet since they don't know anyone either! today has been a good day. no serious longing for home or questioning what the hell i'm doing here. yesterday was rough. i don't know what triggers it. merm. might go see closer tonight with some girls in the hall. heard it was good, an oscar contender and whatnot. of course that's according to rollingstone. yea i bought rollingstone for the flight.
